MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the auto-maneuver lesson! In this lesson, we will go deeper into using the AGC, and how to orient the spacecraft using the PGNCS.

The PGNCS is using onboard systems to point the spacecraft towards a set attitude. To orient, thrusters are fired to start a very slow angular rate to react the destination orientation. The reason for this is fuel consumption and weight.
If you need to help it, you can by using DIRECT mode or the SCS and maneuver manually, but always plan your attitude changes, and ensure you always have enough time after time-scaling.
Before ignition, it is important to verify your attitude with any visual cues you might have, such as the FDAI, windows or the optics. Never trust the attitude blindly.
First of all, separate from the S-IVB by pressing the CSM/LV SEP push button.
The CSM is now free from the Launch Vehicle, currently orbiting Earth.
Use the VIEW SELECTOR to move over to the COMPUTER DSKY.
VERB 06 is used to read and display a memory location specified by the NOUN.
Some of the NOUNs will display one memory location, and it will be drawn into the first register (R1). There are three registers available.
Some NOUNs will display two memory locations, and they will be drawn into R1 and R2.
Lastly, some NOUNs will render three memory locations into R1, R2 and R3.
NOUN 22 will display the desired ICDU angles into R1, R2 and R3. R1 will display roll, R2 will display pitch and R3 will display Yaw.
Start by pressing VERB.
Then press 0.
Then press 6.
Then press NOUN.
Then press 2.
Then press 2.
Lastly, press ENTR.
Each of the numbers have 5 digits, where the last two are used as the decimal part. So if R1 reads 02300, it means roll will be 23.00 degrees. What the five digits represents varies between NOUNs.
Noun 22 displays 00000, 02100, 00000. This means the desired gimbal angles should be set to 0,21,0 degrees relative to the current reference platform.
Please see the Reentry Apollo Flight Manual for a list of all VERBs and NOUNs and how you should read the values displayed.

The AGC can run Programs and Routines to execute functions. We will touch two routines today, R48 to set up the Digital Autopilot, and R62, the Crew Defined Maneuvering routine. R62 is the routine id just like P11 is the ascent program id.
We will first directly edit N22 just as an example and learn how to modify values, and then learn how to auto-maneuver using R48 and R62.

Ok, let's learn how to change values by writing into the computer memory. Verb 21 will allow you to insert values into R1, Verb 22 will allow you to insert values into R2 and Verb 23 will allow you to insert values into R3.
You need to insert all the values, including the sign when inserting values.
Since you ran Verb 06 Noun 22, the specified N22 (N stands for Noun) is displayed. We wish to change the YAW value, namely R3, to 180 to auto-maneuver into retrograde attitude.
We can then use V23 to change R3.
Press VERB.
Press 2.
Press 3.
Press ENTR.

R3 is now blank, and waiting for input. Start by inserting +, followed by 18000, then verify the command follows your intention and is keyed correctly, then press ENTR. Always double-check your command.

When pressing ENTR after that last digit, the value gets inserted into the memory. If you enter something wrong, press CLR to clear and start the entry again. Again, ALWAYS double check before pressing ENTR or PRO!
Are you able to set R2 (pitch) to zero? It shows 21.0 degrees now. Key V 2 2 E + 0 0 0 0 0 E to do this.
Now, verify that the spacecraft control is given to the Command Module Computer by ensuring SC CONT is set to CMC.
Once we start the auto-maneuver, the spacecraft will maneuver to the attitude relative to the stable reference platform (IMU).
Since this is not aligned, we will use the ORDEAL to drive the FDAI to Local Vertical. This will make it easier reach the RETROGRADE direction of the current flight path.
Set the ORDEAL POWER above the left side window to EARTH.
Then set the ORDEAL FDAI 1 to ORB RATE.
Next we will configure the Digital Autopilot (DAP) using the DAP Data Load routine. This is started using V48.
On the DSKY, press VERB.
Then press 4.
Then press 8.
Verify that the DSKY shows Verb 48, then press ENTR.
Then open the (V48) DAP Data Load checklist from the CSM checklists in the Mission Pad. Get familiar with the checklist then press ROGER.
V04N46 should now be flashing. R1 shows the current DAP setup. Each of the 5 digits in R1 has a meaning, and R1 could be read as ABCDE.
With the current values, assuming R1 shows 31111, A=3,B=1,C=1,D=1,E=1.
A is the spacecraft configuration where 3 means CSM & SIVB. We just separated from the SIVB so this should become 1.

D is the deadband (DB) where 0 will set the deadband to 0.5 degrees and 1 will set it to 5.0 degrees. If set to 5, the DAP will try to maintain the attitude within 5 degrees. A small DB is more precise but spends more fuel to maintain the accuracy.
E is the rate. Basically, how fast will the spacecraft move towards a set attitude. Low numbers are desired as it consumes less fuel.
We want to set the DAP to 11111. This will be a CSM configuration with a DB of 5 degrees and a rate of 0.2 degrees/second.
Key Verb 2 1 E + 1 1 1 1 1 but do not yet press ENTR.
This R1 should show +11111. Verify this and press ENTER to insert the configuration.
Then press PRO. V06 N47 should show. This is the current weight data and needs to be filled in. To get the weights you will need to request the weight data from Mission Control.
Press C on the keyboard to toggle the Circular Function keys. Just below the MDC-2 panel where the AGC is located, a circular button named "REQUEST WEIGHTS DATA". Press this to receive the data.
Take a note of the CSM weight (in the Notes section of the Mission Pad for example), we will soon insert it into the AGC using V21E.

The weight might differ but use the number relayed to you. In my case it was 60215 lbs. To do this, Key V 2 1 E + 6 0 2 1 5, then verify the inserted number with the CSM weight you received, and press ENTR to insert it.
The LM weight is bypassed as we selected A=1 in the previous step, so press PRO to proceed to the next, and last step.
In the last step we will need to insert the TVC trim of the SPS. This can be left to zero for now as it's not currently simulated. Hit PRO to end the DAP Setup.
Ok. Now that we have the basics and know how to interact with the AGC, let's give the auto-maneuvering a try using R62 - Crew Defined Maneuvering using V49.
On the DKSY, Key VERB
Then press 4
Then 9
The DSKY should now have 49 in the VERB filed. Once verified, press ENTER to start R62.

Let's open the checklist for this too. On the Mission Pad, under the CSM checklists, find the G&C GENERAL -> (V49) CSM Crew Defined Maneuver checklist and open it. Get familiar with it and use it as a reference for the rest of the lesson.
The first thing you will see is the V06N22 displaying. This is the attitude you wish the spacecraft to maneuver towards.
Since we already modified this, we are all good. But you could use V21, V22, V23 or V25 to modify these.
Press PRO to accept these gimbal angles.
This will copy the values of N22 into N18. V50 requests the auto-maneuvering. Verify that the CMC is in control and the mode is set to AUTO.

Then press PRO to accept the auto-maneuvering. The spacecraft should now start to orient itself towards the desired attitude and the VERB should change from 50 to 06, signaling that the maneuver is in progress.

Notice that the DAP tries to move towards the desired attitude. It uses a slow rate as configured in the DAP setup, and once the desired attitude is reached, it will try to maintain it within the set deadband (5 degrees).
Once the maneuver is complete, V06 will change back to V50. Press ROGER when this happens.
Once the maneuver is complete, V06 will change back to V50. Press ROGER when this happens.
The manuever is complete. You can fine align the maneuver again by pressing PRO when you see V50. This will again change V50 to V06, and return to V50 when complete.
If you are satisfied with the attitude, you can press ENTR during V50 to end the routine. Do this now, you should see the routine completes.
This concludes the auto-maneuver lesson. Use this method to position the spacecraft attitude.
Good job!

Title: Lesson 7 - Automaneuver
Description: The Computer is used to maneuver the spacecraft. In this lesson, we will take a look at how to do this. We will learn how to read, monitor and write to the AGC memory, and how to orient the spacecraft using the PGNCS.
